"Well, when I'm on a table or something, I get to
know people by their arms and hands; and when I'm
on the floor, I get to know them by their feet."

"Oh my gosh -- my face is funny enough to look at,
never mind my feet." She gently wraps her fingers
round you and sets you down on the floor, then she
herself sits up, placing her feet down beside you.
She's in a high heeled sandal, without a stocking.
What's she talking about, you wonder. Her face is
beautiful; and her feet -- they aren't bad either,
as feet go.

A technician directs your eyes upon a monitor. On
it, You see yourself standing beside Kelly's feet.
Then -- you see Regis walk onto the screen -- just
as small as you! He's standing there on the other
side of Kelly's feet. You then turn away from the
monitor and look over to where he therefore should
really be, but he isn't there. A special effect!

So you glance back up at the monitor, and watch as
Regis points to Kelly's feet. "Now that's funny,"
he says. The giant foot beside him makes as if it
takes a swipe at him. He makes as if the foot has
just hit him, and he tumbles onto the ground, then
rolls offscreen.

At that they break for a commercial. Kelly gently
picks you up and congratulates you for a wonderful
performance. Your mom comes from behind a set and
Kelly hands you back to her, thanking her for such
a wonderful son, then rushing off to the adjoining
set. Your mom stares at her, starry-eyed.

"Oh, isn't this glorious?" she says. You doubt if
she's even aware that this show just did precisely
what she didn't want it to do: exploit your size.
1212221112112222222212211121121121221211.title: Five Minutes of Stardom

1212221112112222222212211121121121221211.content:
After the show, you spend the remainder of the day
sight-seeing. Among the stores you patronize is a
top-of-the-line doll emporium. It's the only spot
in the world, you figure, that keeps somewhere, be
it on display or in a storeroom, decent clothes in
literally every size. You and your Mom spend alot
of time (and even more money) shopping for you in
there. Julie does some shopping in there as well;
though for what, you don't know -- and are wary to
find out. The closest thing she's got to any sort
of doll collection ... is you.

Early the next morning, as you and your family get
ready to go to the airport, you find out what your
sister was concealing in that tiny shopping bag of
hers. "It's a disguise," she says, "to keep those
obnoxious airport security ladies' hands off you."
You watch anxiously as her fingers reach deep into
the bag and pull out ...

"Mom! Julie's gonna try to make me wear a dress!"

"No, Mom -- it's a costume." She shows it to your
mother. It is a period piece, something like what
a Dutch milkmaid might have worn two hundred or so
years ago. She even bought for the overall look a
flaxen wig of long pigtails. "I thought if Markie
looked like a little doll, we could get those dumb
airport ladies to leave him alone."

"Mom!"

"Mark, your sister spent her own money on that, to
save you from embarrassment."

"Save me from embarrassment!" you say to yourself.
"She doesn't know what embarrassment is!" Yet you
realize from the tone of her voice that there's no
sense arguing with your mother, so you submit your
body to Julie's latest scheme. She dresses you up
and then, to your horror, takes out of her purse a
couple of almost empty tubes of makeup. "The lady
who made up your face in the studio yesterday said
I could take these," Julie says. She smears your
face with what almost looks like clown white, does
your eyebrows with a finely sharpened brown pencil
and then, with the blunt end of a toothpick, daubs
your lips and cheeks with rosy red. Even your mom
squeals with delight at the results, and takes out
her camera for a photo shoot. All you're thinking
about is with what perverse delight the gal at the
photo place will develop this roll of film.

However, as you will have to admit again and again
in upcoming months, Julie's little ruse does work;
airport security passes you by without any special
treatment. It is difficult trying to remain stiff
and glassy-eyed as security guards rummage through
the bag in which your sister is carrying you. But
thank goodness no one notices that you're really a
teenage male made up to look like a dairy maid.

Well, not until you get home, anyway. Both Stacie
and Pierre are waiting to greet you as you arrive.
"I'll never live this one down," you think.
1212221112112222222212211121121121221211.title: Dollman

1212221112112222222212211121121121221211.content:
Your mother carries you in the house, and sets you
upon a table in the living room, while Julie flops
on the sofa in front of the TV. Stacie and Pierre
follow close behind. Only now do they get a first
look at you. They try to suppress their laughter,
but can't, exploding in a sudden outburst. In the
midst of their laughter, you yell out: "Why didn't
she make me up like a ... a GI Joe or something?"

Your mother's brow wrinkles into a quizzical look.
She turns to Julie. "Why didn't you?"

"Hm?"

"Why didn't you?"

"Didn't I what?"

"Make him up like a GI Joe or something?"

"Oh," Julie yawns, stretching her long body out on
the sofa, as she surfs the TV with a remote, "That
would have been so uninteresting."

Your mother's whole face drops. She looks down at
you. You shrug. "She got you again, Mom."

"I guess she did," your Mom says, looking at Julie
blithely pretending not to hear what she obviously
is hearing. "Yes, she definitely did."

So life goes on as usual -- only the usual becomes
alot better than it was. You become overnight the
most popular kid in the school. The football team
dubs you their mascot; before every game, each one
of the players rubs you on his head for luck.

But both you and they know that there's a lot more
to their winning streak than that; it's really all
about their quarterback Pierre. His leadership on
and off the field hustles them right to the state
championship; he becomes the state's player of the
year, and receives offers for full scholarships to
the top universities in the country. Yet whenever
he acknowledges another award or does an interview
for the media, he always attributes the major part
of his success to you.

Stacie has her own share in fame and success. She
gets back on the track team, and boosts the team's
victories enough to lead them up to the regionals.
She also enjoys a renewed popularity in the school
-- thanks to her association with you.

But all good things must come to an end, including
high school. You, already voted Most Popular, now
are chosen valedictorian for your graduation. You
deliver your address standing on a raised platform
set atop the podium. As at that assembly given in
your honor, behind you is an enormous screen which
displays an image of you big enough for all in the
audience to see. And the topic of your address?
"Learning to Live with the Little Things in Life."

But we're getting ahead of ourselves. A few weeks
prior to graduation day is, of course, prom night.
Pierre already has Stacie for his date, and so you
decide that you'd like to ask -- Elissa. You have
felt sorry for her; her popularity plummeted after
Craig Bradley's arrest. But how will you ask her?
She has seemed almost afraid to go near you, as if
she were some sort of leper or something. But you
know where she sits in the library (she spents her
lunch hours there, to get away from people). With
Pierre's help, you get on the table and take cover
behind some books. At a few minutes before twelve
she arrives and sits down. You call out her name.
She looks around the room nervously. You step out
from the book shelf. You yell up to her: "No, I'm
down here!" She looks down and jumps back. "Hey,
come on! I'm not going to bite you -- it wouldn't
hurt that much, even if I did. I just want to ask
you something." Now you're the one who's nervous.
"Um ... Elissa ... are you going to the ... do you
want me to take you to the ... could I take you to
the ... prom?"

She hangs her head. "That's not funny." she says.

"Elissa, look at me." She does so. "I'm not here
to hurt you. I'm really asking you to go out with
me to the prom. But then (now you hang your head)
it's possible that you're the one who doesn't want
me."

"You're serious. You ... want me?"

"Elissa." You hold out your hands to her. Slowly,
apprehensively, she extends an index finger toward
you. You take it in both your hands. "I've never
been mean to you, ever -- have I?" She shakes her
head no. "Well, I'm not going to begin to now. I
really want to take you to the prom. So how about
it? Will you say yes?" She's speechless. "Hey,"
you say, "You once called me your boyfriend, but I
never did ask you on a date. So I owe you one."

She draws back her finger, then -- opens her palm.
You step into it. She closes her hand around you
and brings you to her now tear-stained cheek. It's
that kind of moment when it's actually nice to get
drenched. "Thank you." she repeats, over and over
again.
1212221112112222222212211121121121221211.title: Senior Moments

choices: You have to convince a family member.
You have to convince a friend.
1212221112112222222212211121121121221211.content:
You remain pressed to her cheek, wetter and saltier with each new tear, until the bell rings for class. Elissa puts you down, gathers her books, thanks you again tearfully, and starts to leave. Halfway out the door, she stops, pauses, turns, and walks back toward you with a puzzled look. “Who brought you here anyway?”
“Pierre.”
“Why isn’t he here to take you to class?”
“I have someone else to take me to class.”
“Oh,” she says, starts walking away again, then turns. “Who?”
You grin at her.
“Me? But ... if people see you with me ...”
“Yeah, well ... they’d better get used to it -- I mean, if you’re gonna be my prom date.”
“Oh, yeah” she says, then looks aghast. “He left you here alone ... with me?”
“Yep. I told him to.” She starts looking around. “Believe me, he’s not here,” you say. “Nobody is -- except you and me.”
“But ... you didn’t know what I was gonna say ... or do. I could have ...” She squeezes closed her eyes, and bites her lip. You shudder a bit at what she left unsaid.
“Yeah, well, I guess I took my chances. But hey -- things turned out all right, right?”
She shakes her head yes.
“Right. So I’m really gonna be late to class unless you take me there, right now. Please?”
She nods, composes herself as best she can, and wraps her fingers around you. “Oh!” She releases you suddenly, and half giggles between sobs. “You’re all wet. Here.” She fishes out a kleenex from her sweatshirt pocket, and tries wiping you off.
“That’ll do,” you say, after a moment. “Let’s go.” She picks you up and holds you to her bosom with one hand, hitching her books onto her hip with the other, and hurries you off to class. Not many people notice you with her, until she reaches your classroom. There, as she carries you to your desk, you observe all the gaping mouths and widened eyes, and you say to yourself, “Markie ol’ boy -- you done good.”
Maybe so. But you have a hard time convincing some people.
1212221112112222222212211121121121221211.title: NOT THE PROM YET

choices: She breaks off her date with Pierre.
1212221112112222222212211121121121221211.content:
First, there’s Stacie. When she hears about your deal with Elissa --Whoa!
“After all she did to you -- and to me?”
“Yeah, but ... that ended a long time ago and ... I couldn’t stand seeing her sad like that all the time. I know what it feels like to have the whole school hating you.”
“Yeah me too -- thanks to her. So if now everybody hates her -- good! She deserves it. We didn’t. I can’t believe you.”
Then she forces out of you that it was Pierre who took you to the library -- and left you to contend with Elissa alone. It doesn’t matter how much you tell Stacie that you put him up to it. She’s mad; so mad, that as she storms out of Pierre’s house, it really sounds like she’s breaking off her prom date with him. Eeech! You didn’t figure on this happening.
1212221112112222222212211121121121221211.title: The Trouble with Stacie

1212221112112222222212211121121121221211.content:
Yet Pierre seems kind of calm about the whole thing. He drives you home and carries you in, assuring you that everything will be okay. A few hours later, his car drives up to your house again. This time, he’s with Stacie. The two of them go up to your bedroom where you’re already asleep in your pj’s (that’s what you do when you’re depressed). She scoops your half-asleep body out of bed and holds you up to her face, gliding her free index finger along the tiny toes sticking out below her clenched pinkie (she’s always loved doing that). She apologizes for getting mad at you, and is kind of ashamed of herself. She explains that after Pierre left you at your house, he went to her house, and managed to calm her down enough to reason with her. He pointed out that, what you just did for Elissa, you once did for her -- had compassion on her even though she was really cruel to you, forgave her, and asked her to be your friend. She gets teary-eyed just thinking about it. “Where would I be,” she says, “if you hadn’t done that for me?” And even though she doesn’t know how she’ll be able to be civil with Elissa, she promises to try -- especially since her prom date, Pierre, plans on driving you and your date to and from the prom and sitting with you while you’re there.
“Guess you folks who got religion are more used to this forgiveness thing than I am -- I just hope you can forgive me now. Can you?” You playfully chuck her giant chin, and she plants a kiss over your face.
“Thank you, Pierre.” you say to yourself.
1212221112112222222212211121121121221211.title: Apologies

choices: You decide to go to the prom with someone else.
1212221112112222222212211121121121221211.content:
But then, there’s Elissa. One day, after English class, as you’re waiting for Stacie to pick you up, Elissa (who also attended the class, and sat near the window) walks by you and without looking at you drops a note atop the desk on which you’re sitting. You unfold it and lay it out in front of you. It reads: “I’ve changed my mind. I don’t want to go to the prom. Thanks anyway. Elissa.” What’s this about?
You decide to find out. At lunch you get Pierre to take you back to the library and leave you again at the place Elissa frequents. Again she sits there and again you step out from behind some books to surprise her. This time Elissa gasps, grabs her books and leaves. You cry out that you’ll need someone to take you to class next period, but she doesn’t stop for you. However, before the bell rings for class, Pierre arrives to pick you up. Elissa dropped him a note at lunch telling him to do so.
You ask Pierre to do some sleuthing for you. After school, he meets you and Stacie in the school courtyard, and makes his report. From what he was able to gather, Elissa heard kids saying that you’re only taking her to the prom because she’s a loser and you feel sorry for her, and that you would have really preferred to take Stacie but Pierre asked Stacie first.
Now Stacie gets really angry,: “She dumped you because of that?” Whereupon she jumps up from the bench, and runs off crying, “I’m going to find that jerk!”
“Pierre, stop her!”
“I can’t stop her.”
“She’ll make things even worse!”
“But I can’t stop her. She won’t listen.”
Instead, Pierre drives you home and takes you up to your room, where you do what you always do in such circumstances: you get into your pajamas, pull your head over the covers and mope.
1212221112112222222212211121121121221211.title: What’s the Trouble with Elissa?

1212221112112222222212211121121121221211.content:
You want to go to the prom with Elissa. It’s not that you’re desparate for a date; you know there are lots of girls who would love to go with you to the prom. They flirt with you all the time, wiggling their fingers at you as they walk by the desk you’re on (or their toes when you’re on the floor and they’re in sandals). But you’re stubborn, and the way you feel right now, if you can’t go with Elissa to the prom, you’re not going.
You fall asleep in your gloom. An hour or so later, you wake up to the sound of at least one car door slamming. A moment later Stacie enters your room. You pretend to be asleep, but she shakes you with her finger. “Hey -- wake up.” You roll over and open an eye to her. “Well, I really told her off” she says. “I told her what a jerk she is, how selfish she is, how insensitive she is, and how bad she made you feel. I told her that if you feel sorry for her it’s because you know how she feels, and she never gave you a chance to explain that, and that was the meanest thing she could have done. I told her off good.”
You roll away from her and groan: “Ohhhhh -- just go away.”
“Don’t you like what I did?”
“Go away!”
“But I haven’t finished ...”
“GO AWAY!”
“But ...”
“MOM!”
Your mother comes to the door. “I‘m here. What is it?”
“Make her go away.”
“Mark! What are you saying?”
“MAKE HER GO AWAY!”
“Mark!”
“I DON’T WANT TO TALK TO HER!”
Your mother turns to Stacie. “I guess you’d better go.”
“But, Mrs. Letellier, he won’t let me explain ...”
“I know. Maybe you can explain another time.”
“But, Mrs. Letellier ...”
1212221112112222222212211121121121221211.title: Moping

1212221112112222222212211121121121221211.content:
As all this is going on, you hear footsteps coming up the stairs, and a third female voice: “Should I come in now?”
Who was that? You roll over and look toward the door.
Elissa!
Stacie gestures her up to your dollhouse. Elissa walks up nervously and peeks in.
“Hi.”
“Uh ... hi.”
“Do you mind if I’m ... here?”
“No, I guess not.”
“Okay. Do you mind if I ... tell you something?”
“I guess not. If you want.”
“Okay. Well .. um ... I’m sorry ... I mean, um ... I’m real sorry, and ... and I’d like to ... to go to the prom ... with you. Please?”
After she says this, a giggle escapes her. She desparately looks over to Stacie for help.
Laughing at a time like this? What is going on here?
“No Mark,” Stacie says, “It’s not what you’re thinking. Elissa wants to go to the prom with you. Really. It’s just that, well ... when we were downstairs, I was telling her how cute you look in your pj’s and ....”
Now it’s your mother who fails to stifle a laugh. She apologizes, and excuses herself, leaving you alone with your friends. You, however, roll away from them and pull the covers over your head.
“Uh, oh,” says Stacie, “Don’t you want to go to the prom with Elissa?”
“Yes!” You say from under your covers. “But cut out the cutsie stuff!”
“Liss!” Stacie says to Elissa, “He said yes!” Then she says to you, “But I can’t cut out the cutsie stuff, Markie, ‘cause you’re even cuter when you’re in your pj’s AND MAD.”
“Go away!”
“Isn’t he cute?” she says to Elissa. Then she starts shaking your dollhouse stand. “Mark! Get out of bed! It’s an earthquake!”
“You’ve been hanging around Julie too long! Now go away!” But Stacie doesn’t go away. Instead, she stealthily pulls back your sheet from the foot of the bed, revealing the soles of your bare feet. “See how cute?” she says to Elissa.
“Cut that out!” you say, and draw your legs up further. But Stacie only pulls the sheet up further. With thumb and forefinger she grabs your two legs at the ankle, and tickles your feet with her pinkie nail. You try to kick yourself free. but of course are no match for her. “Let me go!”
Abruptly she releases you. “Okay Liss.” Stacie says, “We’d better go. Sleeping Beauty’s in no mood for games right now. Bye Markie.”
“Bye Mark,” says Elissa, “Thank you, and ... um ... I’m sorry ... if I laughed at you.”
“It wasn’t your fault,” you grumble. “It was Stacie’s.”
“Aren’t you going to forgive me, Mark?” Stacie asks. “I hear that we’re supposed to forgive each other.”
She’s got you there.
“Oh, yeah. Well, we’ll ... we’ll talk about it tomorrow. But go away now.”
“He’ll forgive me.” She says to Elissa. “He always does. So -- we’d better go. Come on, Liss. Love you, Mark.”
Stacie pats your head with her finger and the two girls leave the room. You hear their footsteps down the stairs, and a moment later, two car doors opening and slamming, one right after the other, and Stacie’s car driving away. You snuggle up cozily under your covers, and sigh a sigh of relief. Everything’s all right again.
“Thank you, Stacie.” you say to yourself.
1212221112112222222212211121121121221211.title: More Apologies

1212221112112222222212211121121121221211.content:
The evening of the prom finally arrives, and you’re all spiffed up for the occasion in black tux and white tie -- with even a cummerbund. Pierre, who’s also dressed to the nines, picks up you and Elissa’a corsage at your front door and carries you both down to his car. He slips into the driver’s seat and hands you and the corsage to Stacie, who sits beside him in the front seat, looking so beautiful that you feel like you’re melting in her hand.
Pierre drives you up the driveway of Elissa’a house. He hops out of the car with you and the corsage, marches up to the front door, and tucks you into his breast pocket, in order to free up a hand and ring the bell.
1212221112112222222212211121121121221211.title: Fancy Pants

1212221112112222222212211121121121221211.content:
Immediately Elissa’a father swings open the door.
“Come in come in come in,” he says, shaking Pierre’s hand, and practically pulling him inside. “Well well well -- so you’re the Romeo come to show my daughter a good time tonight, eh? Heh-heh-heh. So what’s your name son?”
“Pierre, sir, but ...”
“Pierre eh? That’s different, eh? Pierre, Pi ... whoo whoo whoo, hold it! You’re not the big football player Pierre?”
“Yes sir, but ...”
“By golly! You’re the big football player! My daughter going to the prom with the best player in the state! Hoo-heee! Atta girl!”
At this point Pierre is dumbstruck. By now Elissa has hurried down a nearby flight of stairs and is witnessing the scene with mounting horror.
“Daddy ... !”
“Of course, I hate to tell you this, son, but you ain’t the first big football star that my pumpkin’s managed to snag for herself. No sir -- there was that Bradley fella ...
“DADDY!”
“Hoo-boy; what an arm he had, eh? I tell ya, now there’s a kid who would have made pro -- guarantee it! -- if he hadn’t gotten himself into the trouble that he did ...”
“DADDY NO!”
“Of course, you can’t trust everything you read -- especially when it comes to that Bradley case! I mean, guns and midgets and ... how small was that shrimp supposed to be, anyway; you know, the one who ratted on him? Two inches? A two inch kid? Who ya kiddin’, right? Hah! Well anyway ...”
“MAMA MAKE HIM STOP!!!”
By now Elissa’s mother is seated on the bottom step, consoling her daughter collapsed in her arms. “ARTHUR, STOP!”
“Huh? What?” He looks down at his daughter. “What are you crying about? You got a date with the biggest hunk in the school, and you’re blubberin’? You think he’s gonna want to take you out, with your purple eye goo smearing down your face like that?” He turns to Pierre. “Ever since the Bradley kid was put away, she’s weepy like this.” He turns again to her. “What’s the matter with you, anyway?”
“Arthur!” Elissa’s mother jumps up and confronts her husband “Will you please, for once in your life, LISTEN?” She then holds out an open palm to Pierre. “May I, for just a moment?” Pierre takes you out of his pocket and sets you in her hand. She closes her hand around you and holds you up to her husband’s face. “Arthur; LOOK!”
“What the...? Oh-my-gawd! That’s ... that’s one of them little figurines they put on a wedding cake!” He glowers at Pierre. “Who told you you could marry my daughter? What have you done to her?”
“Arthur -- no! That boy isn’t Elissa’s date!” She holds you in his face again. “THIS is Elissa’s date!”
At this point you finally manage to gulp out: “G-g-g good evening, sir.”
“Aaah! It’s him! The midget! You’re going out with the midget!”
“Oh Daddy,” Elissa sobs.
“Yes, Arthur.” says her mother, glaring at him. “She’s going out with -- Mark. This is Mark Letellier.”
The situation finally dawns on him.
“Oh. Hm. Well ... how was I to know? I mean, it would be nice if a fella could be told what’s going on in his own home, you know!”
Elissa’s mother looks at him sternly. “Arthur ...”
He suddenly attempts a gentler tone. “But then ... I don’t mean that I mind this ... person ... going out with my daughter, if ... she wants to ... put up with that. After all, if you ... can’t go out with the best throwing arm in the state, this little fellow is ... well, he’s something of a celebrity himself, isn’t he? In his own ... small way ...”
Elissa’s mother interjects, in a calmer but still commanding tone: “Arthur.”
“Huh?”
“I’m taking Elissa upstairs to fix her mascara. You go into the kitchen. Supper’s ready.”
“Ah! Pot roast and red cabbage. Yes. Yes indeed. But ... what about the pictures?”
“We’ve already taken plenty of pictures of Elissa in her prom dress, and I’m sure she’ll be fine with that.”
“Oh. Well, yes ... of course ... pictures of her with ... him ... would pretty much just be more pictures ... of her ...”
“Arthur. Go into the kitchen.”
“Yes. Well, pumpkin, you have a nice little time for yourself with your nice little ... with him. And Pierre, you come by anytime. My wife makes a wonderful ... red cabbage. Yes.” He backs into the swinging doors of the kitchen, and disappears.
Elissa’s mother holds you up to her face and says to you and Pierre. “My daughter and I both apologize for my husband.” She hands you back to Pierre and attends again to her daughter. “Come on now honey. We’ll clean you up, and everything will be okay.” She helps Elissa to her feet, and guides her up the stairs.
1212221112112222222212211121121121221211.title: Father Knows Best?

choices: You convince her to go with you.
You fail to convince her to go with you.
1212221112112222222212211121121121221211.content:
You and Pierre exchange looks. He’s sweating. So are you.
“I need to change my shirt.” you say.
“Yeah?” replies Pierre, “I gotta change more than that. Oh man!”
Stacie, who could hear from the car some sort of commotion going on, comes to the door and slips inside. “What is going on in here?” she whispers.
Just then Elissa’s mother appears at the top of the stairs, and with her finger to her lips beckons you and your friends up to her. As you reach her she says: “She’s still pretty upset. I thought maybe you kids could help me with her.” She leads the three of you into Elissa’s bedroom. Elissa is seated at her vanity, still heaving heavy sobs. Pierre tiptoes in and sets you in front of her. You stand on a jewelry box and look up at her.
“Elissa?”
She looks down at you and then turns her head away. “My dad’s ruined everything.”
“No he hasn’t. Really. We can have a good time tonight. We can have a great time.”
“I’m too embarrassed...”
“But why? I mean, it’s not like the whole school was there. It was just Pierre and me, and we’re okay with it.”
This only makes her cry harder. “What the matter now?”
“You guys are so ... nice to me.”
Oh no, you think to yourself, let’s not get into that; not now. You look up helplessly at your friends.
1212221112112222222212211121121121221211.title: Don’t Back Out Now

1212221112112222222212211121121121221211.content:
Just then, a voice booms from downstairs. “Hey, where’s my pistachio nut ice cream?”
“Oh dear,” Elissa’s mom says, and calls down, “There’s more in the basement freezer.” Then gasping, she cries: “But DON’T YOU MOVE! I’ll get it for you. Sorry kids,” she says to you, “I’ll be back.”
Stacie quickly switches the subject: “Liss, I wasn’t there for what happened, but if your father embarrassed you, well -- we’ve all been embarrassed by our parents at one time or another.”
Great tack, Stace!
“Yeah,” you say, “If you want to hear about embarrassing moments with parents, I can tell you some real doozies! Like the stupid poem about the bumblebee. Every time guests would come to the house, my mom would dress me up in this bumblebee suit, and make me act out this dumb poem. It was bad enough when I was five -- but she even made me do it when I was fifteen! And sometimes in front of kids my age. It was awful.”
You then act it out for her:

I saw my friend, the bumblebee
Alight upon a rose.
I saw him fly away from me
With pollen on his toes.

And yet, I hope you don’t suppose
He’s anything but neat;
On entering another rose
he always wipes his feet.

I think I’ll try to be a bee
By doing what he does:
I’ll fly from rose to peony
And buzz and buzz and buzz.

And if you grab me by the wing,
I’ll sting you in the thumb
By sticking out the pointy thing
That’s coming from my bum.

Stacie has a big grin on her face. “I’m glad I was here for this.” You smile at her warily.
But at least, after a few minutes, you’ve got Elissa beginning to laugh with you, as Stacie works on redoing the smeared makeup.
“So come on, Liss,” you say, “come on and have a nice little time for yourself with your nice little ... with me.”
“I hope they serve red cabbage,” Pierre says.
“Red cabbage ... Ick!” says Elissa.
“I heard that!” Elissa’s mom now steps in the room.
“Oops. Sorry Mom.”
“You think I don’t know how you feel about red cabbage?” she turns to us and says, “Her father insists on red cabbage at least once a week. Poor Elissa.”
“Yep,” Elissa says, “Poor me.”
“It looks like your not such a poor thing right now. Feeling better?” Elissa nods. “Good; and I see you’re nicely made up again. So are all systems go?” You all nod. She looks at her watch. “Hmmm. You’re already a little late. So what do you want to do? Go right now, or take a few pictures -- in here?”
1212221112112222222212211121121121221211.title: Make ‘em Laugh

choices: You fail to pin on the corsage.
1212221112112222222212211121121121221211.content:
You agree to the pictures.
Elissa’s mom snaps some photos with just you and Elissa, and some with all four of you. And she takes a video of you pinning on Elissa’s corsage and of Elissa pinning on your boutonniere -- neither of which is too gracefully accomplished. Your boutonniere is a bud from a bonsai rose bush, requiring a pin practically nano-sized. Elissa tries to pin the rose to your lapel first with her fingers and the naked eye, then with her fingernails and a magnifying glass, and eventually with a pair of tweezers and a microscope from a junior science kit found in the basement. But she keeps dropping the pin, and you keep having to find it for her. She finally is content to touch her finger to your hand as you do the pinning yourself.
1212221112112222222212211121121121221211.title: The Boutonniere

1212221112112222222212211121121121221211.content:
Your attempt to pin her corsage is no less awkward, since you too at first insist on doing it yourself. You stand on her shoulder as she hands you the corsage, which is so big and heavy that you end up falling over and crumpling under it against her neck. So, you give in, and she holds it. She hands you a pin which is almost as long as you are tall. You have to thrust it through both the backing of the corsage and her shoulder strap. You decide to give it all you’ve got on the first try, so you haul off and jab! You miss the corsage backing altogether, but do manage to stick it somewhat into the shoulder strap.
Elissa feels the pin going into her strap and flinches; you lose your footing, and fall off her shoulder. At first you’re able to hang onto the pin, but it is barely embedded, dislodges under your weight, and sends you slipping down her bosom. Desparately with feet and hands you try to clamber back up to her shoulder, but continue slipping, until you get a foot lodged in her cleavage. She yanks you out, and you both decide that she should pin the corsage herself while you hold the pin with her.
As if all this weren’t embarrassing enough, Stacie now points to Elissa’a bosom and giggles. Your shoes left skid marks on her skin!
1212221112112222222212211121121121221211.title: The Corsage

choices: You finally make it to the prom.
1212221112112222222212211121121121221211.content:
It is finally time to leave. When Elissa tries to hand you to Pierre, he points out, and you concur, that she should be holding you herself tonight. The four of you now head for the stairs, but Elissa’s mom stops her, uncomfortable with the skid marks on her front. “I know it’s cute,” she says, “but it isn’t becoming. Go into the bathroom and wash up. Your friends can wait for you in the car, and I’ll hold Mark until you come out.”
Actually, this gives Elissa’s mom a chance to talk with you alone. She holds you up to her lips and whispers in your ear, “Thank you.”
“Excuse me, ma’am?”
“Thank you.”
“Um ... for what, ma’am?”
“Oh ... lots of things.” She looks toward the bathroom, and says, as if to herself, “It’s been a difficult couple of years; but it could have been a lot worse. Oh, was I relieved when that boy was locked away!” She holds you up and looks at you. “Does that sound awful?” You shrug your shoulders, sheepishly. She looks to the bathroom again. “Her father didn’t understand. He was so taken with her dating a football star that he couldn’t see what harm that boy was doing. Our baby was beginning to act and dress like a ... well, you know. Oh, I don’t say it wasn’t painful to see her lose all her friends as she did, but I still say she was better off moping around at home than hanging out with him who-knows-where and doing who-knows-what. And she’s not so depressed now, since you asked her to the prom. It’s like you saved her life twice. So I guess that’s why I’m saying thank you and -- do you mind if I give you a kiss?”
Of course you acquiesce, so she covers your face with her puckered lips and gives you a tender smooch. She looks down at you and smiles, and presses you to her bosom, as Elissa opens the bathroom door. She takes you from her mother, and they kiss goodbye.
“Remember,” her mom says, “call if you’re going to be out later than two.”
“I will. I promise. Bye mom.” Elissa hurries down the stairs with you, and out the door.
1212221112112222222212211121121121221211.title: A Mother’s Concern

1212221112112222222212211121121121221211.content:
You arrive at the prom a good twenty minutes late, which Elissa blames on herself; so you and your friends make light of it, assuring her that ‘important’ people like yourselves are supposed to be late. And indeed, when you enter the banquet hall, a crowd of friends and wanna-be friends gather round you. “Hi Mark!” “Hi Stace!” “Hi Pierre!” “Hi Liss! Wow! Love the dress!”
Yes, more than a few of your classmates come up and welcome Elissa with the rest of you. And as the evening wears on, it becomes ever more apparent that the class, as a whole, is comfortable with her again. Oh, there are a few girls who still seem to be snubbing her; but they’re invariably girls who had been doing alot of flirting with you in the months prior to the prom, and are invariably now either without a date or with a dweeby date. So you assure Elissa that they’re just jealous.
1212221112112222222212211121121121221211.title: Acceptance

choices: You go off with someone else.
1212221112112222222212211121121121221211.content:
And so, as they say ‘a good time was had by all.’ You eat off of Elissa’s plate, and remind her of the first meal you shared with her. On your way to grabbing a pea, you slip on the gravy and almost land in the mashed potatoes, but she swipes you up in the nick of time.
And when everyone else is on the dance floor, well -- at first you and Elissa sit it out. Or at least she’s sitting. You step up to her and ask, “Mademoiselle, may I have zee pleasure of ziss dance?” and gesture to receive her hand. She removes her glove, stands her index and middle finger on the table, and drapes her thumb over your shoulder, as your one hand grabs her pinkie and the other pulls her hand close to you. Her fingers and your feet coordinate beautifully, as you dance around the table, as far as her arm can reach. You begin to attract attention and pretty soon a crowd of amused onlookers surround you. You end up dancing with the hand of one girl after another -- though Elissa’s hand is still your best partner.
1212221112112222222212211121121121221211.title: On the Table

1212221112112222222212211121121121221211.content:
Then someone cries out, “Clear the floor!” and the next thing you know, some feminine hand whisks you off the table and sets you down in the middle of the dance floor. A bunch of girls kick off their shoes and run up to you, vying with each other to dance closest to you. You’re surrounded at close range by a bevy of beautiful bare feet stepping over you and one another.
Then one girl pops an after dinner mint in her mouth, drops onto her stomach, and starts blowing a gale of minty breath at you. Soon other girls do the same, until they encircle you, and send you blowing from one to the other of their giant female faces.
Now one by one they sit up and in the same tight circle try to catch you between their toes. You attempt in vain to fight off the entanglement of feet. It’s a literal fight toe to toe, as they flatten you to the ground or toss you helplessly back and forth, until one of the most fetching sets of digits clamps you at the waist, pulls you away from the fleshy melee, sets you down and covers you over. It takes the other girls a good minute to realize that you’re no longer in the circle. You hear them searching for you from girl to girl; then: “Hey! Look at Elissa! Hey, Elissa! Lift up your feet!” You feel the pressure from the soles pressed down on you suddenly eased; you again breathe freely and see light; you look up and see high above you a mountain range of teeny-bopper faces looking down on you giggling. Elissa, who had been sitting on the floor, now rises to her full height, reaches down, picks you up and holds you high above her head. “I win!” she says. The other girls laugh and clap.
1212221112112222222212211121121121221211.title: Floor Show

1212221112112222222212211121121121221211.content: The party finally ends. You’re pretty dishevelled, and Elissa takes you into the ladies’ room to clean you up -- creating something of a commotion. She can only do so much. A few of you comb the dance floor for your missing shoe, which you never do find (the next morning a girl discovers it lodged between her toes). At least however, you notice one of the girl’s shoes, for which she is frantically searching, under a heating vent behind a table. She retrieves it herself on hands and knees, since it’s way beyond your ability to move.
1212221112112222222212211121121121221211.title: The Party's Over

1212221112112222222212211121121121221211.content: From the banquet hall Pierre, according to plan, drives the four of you down to Hadley Beach. You and they had the foresight to leave bathing suits and a change of clothes at your family bungalow, and so you all now indulge in some midnight swimming. Elissa ties you securely to a chain around her neck, and for double protection, jams you down her cleavage, as you hold on tightly to her bra (you have to be so careful in the ocean).
1212221112112222222212211121121121221211.title: By the Sea

1212221112112222222212211121121121221211.content: Eventually you and your date come to shore and begin building a sand fort; your friends soon join you. At your instruction Pierre runs up to the bungalow and retrieves from an old toy chest a set of army men, and some Fisher Price figurines. You’re soon staging a battle, boys and the U.S. army against girls and the Fisher Price people. You and Pierre defend the fort; you act as general and Pierre mans your troops, while Elissa and Stacie man their troops. The fighting is evenly matched until the enemy bring out their secret weapon: army tanks shaped like girls’ pedicured feet which ram into the fort and send you and your men cascading helplessly down to four sets of waiting toes. The enemy holds you hostage in a smelly clam shell until Pierre meets their demands -- which is to carry both the girls (with you in Elissa’s bra) back up to the bungalow.
1212221112112222222212211121121121221211.title: Fortifications

1212221112112222222212211121121121221211.content:
At about 2 a.m. you head for home, and pull into your driveway about 45 minutes later. Your mom gets up to greet you, as does Julie and two of her friends, who are at your house for a sleepover. Your mom is slightly miffed when she hears of your female classmates’ treatment of you on the dance floor, although Julie finds it hilarious.
As your mom heads again for bed, Julie leads you all to the back porch where, of course, she entertains your friends and hers with parlor tricks at your expense (which is easier for her to do with your mom asleep).
At Stacie’s request, Julie dresses you up in the bumblebee costume and makes you recite the poem again. Julie then announces that you will perform a second poem. As she takes you upstairs for a costume change, you loudly object, but she keeps you cupped in her hand, muffling your protests so your mom won’t hear you and wake up. A few moments later she returns, sets you on the table dressed in a stupid frog outfit, and proceeds to recite the following, while you reluctantly repeat the chorus.

Observe this poor, unhappy frog
(Ribbit-ribbit-ribbit)
Unhappy since a polliwog
(Ribbit-ribbit-ribbit)
Whose claim that he’s a handsome prince
That needs a kiss does not convince
A single girl to go agog.
(Ribbit-ribbit-ribbit)

It’s true that he to some extent
(Ribbit-ribbit-ribbit)
Has gotten girls to give consent
(Ribbit-ribbit-ribbit)
To kiss him, yet he wonders why
That after just a single try
They give up the experiment.
(Ribbit-ribbit-ribbit)

So please believe, O pretty Miss,
(Ribbit-ribbit-ribbit)
That such a metamorphosis
(Ribbit-ribbit-ribbit)
From homely frog to handsome prince
Has only failed to happen since
You've got to kiss him more -- like this!

Before you even have a chance to repeat the refrain, Julie swipes you up and, despite your defiant squirmings, smothers you with a slobbering kiss.
“Or this!” Julie’s friend Daisy grabs you from her and does the same.
“Or this!” Their friend Luanne grabs you from Daisy and practically sticks your whole head in her mouth.
“Or this!” Stacie takes you from Luanne, wipes you off, and plants on you a distinctively gentler kiss.

All the while Elissa looks upon this entertainment with amazement.
1212221112112222222212211121121121221211.title: Home, James

1212221112112222222212211121121121221211.content:
At about 4:30 a.m. you decide to call it a night. Pierre drives Stacie home. Julie, with her new license, drives Elissa home -- and of course you come along. Elissa carries you up the front porch; Julie, your transport back to the car, tags a few yards behind, and stops at the bottom step, trying to look like she’s not looking.
You help Elissa fish around her purse for her house key, and hold it with her as she unlocks the door and steps inside.
“Well,” she sighs, as she looks down at you in her hand, “this is it.”
“Yep, this is it.”
“And so ... um ... well, good night.”
“Yep, good night.” You stare at her dumbly. There’s an awkward pause.
“Hey dodo,” whispers Julie, “Don’t you know what you’re supposed to do now?”
“Oh yeah.” You motion Elissa to bring you close, and you give her a peck on her giant chin.
“No no!” says Julie, “You’re not supposed to give her a kiss like that. You’re supposed to give her -- a kiss! Show him, Elissa.”
Elissa smiles coyly and closes the door. After a good minute and a half, she opens it again, and Julie steps up to recieve from Elissa your now limp and steamy body.
“Are you still alive?” Julie asks.
“No,” you drone, “I’m in heaven.”
1212221112112222222212211121121121221211.title: The End of a Perfect Day

choices: No, there is still someone else.
1212221112112222222212211121121121221211.content:
Those reading your story might assume at this point that Elissa and you now become an item, just as they once might have assumed the same of you and Stacie. Elissa is a good kid, and obviously a monumental kisser, and in fact your prom experience does establish a lasting friendship between you. But romance? It never happens. Instead, she’ll eventually fall in love with a guy studying with her at a junior college, and marry him. It will be a sometimes shaky marriage but will survive, and from it she will bring into the world three children, a girl, a boy, and another girl. The boy, Elliot, will make the high school varsity football team, which will give his inimitable grandfather something more to boast about.
And Stacie? She of course will always remain one of your closest friends -- as will Pierre. And she and Pierre will always remain an item. She will go on to major in sports therapy; he, in pre-med. And when the pressures of a promising football career begin to strain their courtship, forcing him to make a choice, he’ll choose Stacie -- with no regrets. They’ll marry while he’s in med school. She’ll join his Church and apparently take her Catholic religion seriously -- by becoming the happy mother of nine children (but then, she began longing for a large family the day she met Pierre’s).
And you mind none of this, not at this point in your story -- at the threshold of your high school graduation -- nor ever. Your beloved Stacie was never really a heartthrob; any more than Elissa was. In fact, you didn’t really ask Elissa to the prom because you couldn’t ask Stacie. You asked Elissa to the prom because you couldn’t ask ... oh your heart is racing just to think of her! You would have asked her in a heartbeat, had it been appropriate. And you sense that, had it been appropriate, she would have accepted.
1212221112112222222212211121121121221211.title: Life Goes On

choices: You find out one way or the other.
1212221112112222222212211121121121221211.content:
Okay, so some may suspect that what you’re now claiming -- that Mrs. Andrews loves you as you love her -- is just a pipedream. Otherwise -- you can just hear them say -- your story would be too “far-fetched.” After all, a high school student loving his history teacher is one thing; but her returning that love?
But hey, you argue, what if she were quite a young teacher when you first met her in that eleventh-grade history class? What if there’s only eight years difference between you? That may still seem like a lot when you’re sixteen and she’s twenty four, but not quite as much when you’re eighteen and she’s twenty six.
And if we’re talking far-fetched, well: the possibility of any girl desiring you is far-fetched. After all, is a girlfriend eight years older than you as fantastic as a girlfriend thirty five times taller than you? Even if she were the same age as you, even if she were four foot ten instead of five foot ten, it would still be fantastic. Why, if you were to limit your aspirations to the realm of reasonable possibility, you’d be a two-inch tall bachelor the rest of your life.
But you don’t let the gainsayers worry you. You’ve always sensed that she loves you as you love her, and soon, once you’re officially out of high school, once propriety no longer demands a proper student/teacher relationship between you, you’ll have a chance to find out. And it doesn’t take long before ...
1212221112112222222212211121121121221211.title: Your Defense

1212221112112222222212211121121121221211.content:
“Wake up, Sleepyhead.”
Who’s shaking you into consciousness this time? You half open your eyes, and immediately sense that you’re in a strange dollhouse in a strange room. You roll over to get a better look at where you are and whose finger is prodding you. Your eyes focus in on a gargantuan female face framed in long blonde hair. That beautiful familiar face.
“Mrs. Andrews!”
“Mrs. Andrews? My, we are sleepy this morning. Don’t you know who I am?”
If that isn’t Mrs. Andrews you don’t know who it is. You look helplessly perplexed. She laughs.
“You silly man. You really don’t know who I am.”
You can’t answer.
“Well, what do you think this is?”
She holds up the back of her hand, to display a wedding ring. But Mrs. Andrews always wore a wed ...
“And what do you think that is?” Her thumb and forefinger pick up your arm and force your own hand in front of your face.
You’re wearing a wedding band too!
Oh yes -- OH YES! Mrs. Andrews is no longer Mrs. Andrews. She’s ...
“The name is Letellier now,” she says, as if you didn’t know. “Mrs. Mark Letellier.” She pokes you in the tummy. “And don’t you forget it!” She picks you up and gives you a kiss. You see that she’s still in her pajamas, and notice as you look down that she’s not even in her slippers yet. She wiggles her toes for you. “Did you think I’d let anyone but my husband nibble at those the way you did last night?”
Oh (heh!) right -- how could you forget THAT?
She suddenly lifts you to her face, and says, with mock concern: “But we must be careful what we say. He may be listening. You know,” she whispers, “the other little man.”
The other little man? What other little man? There’s another guy in the world like you? What’s he doing in your house? If he dares try to make it with your wife, you’ll kill him, you’ll ...”
1212221112112222222212211121121121221211.title: Awakenings

1212221112112222222212211121121121221211.content:
She laughs again. “What a face! You’re still not awake yet, are you?” She flops down onto her bed, pulls up her pajama top, and sets you on her stomach. You’ve lain on her stomach plenty of times before, but this time something’s different. This time you notice that you’re almost level with her breasts, as if her usually flat tummy had suddenly become a hillock, a mound; as if she’s ...
Ohhh. Ah yessss. Yes yes yes yes yes. What a sweet memory to waken to. You spread your arms and do your best to hug her rounded abdomen, as she strokes your back with her finger.
“I forgot to tell you.” she says. “Yesterday’s ultrasound showed not only that it’s a boy, but also that right now, he’s about two inches long: the same size as you! And at only eleven weeks! At the rate he’s growing, I’m afraid you won’t be doing too many bottle feedings.”
“Or diaper changings,” you add.
“Hm, I don’t know. What if I were to buy you a little red dump truck -- with tiny shovel to match?”
“Make that two tiny shovels. We’re a team.”
“Whatever you say, Big Daddy.”
You look up at her as she throws you a midair kiss. You return it, then snuggle her belly, and barrage it with kisses. She picks you up, rolls herself over, and sets you atop her pillow. She purses her gigantic lips and slowly leans toward you as you lay there, ecstatically helpless, awaiting one of her long, passionate, totally debilitating, thoroughly exhilarating kisses ...
1212221112112222222212211121121121221211.title: Oh, Baby!

1212221112112222222212211121121121221211.content:
“Hey, Sleepyhead, I said wake up!”
Huh ... ? Wha ...? Oh, that voice. You know that voice. That was Julie’s voice, your sister’s voice, the same old familiar voice that has woken you up a thousand times before.
You groan. You groan, and don’t really care if Julie, and the whole world with her, hears you.
It was a dream. That scene with you and your beautiful bride, was nothing but a dream.
You are just awake enough to know that what had seemed so real was not real at all. You now begin to second guess everything else that has hitherto seemed so real. Was any of it real -- Elissa and Craig Bradley, Stacie and Pierre? The prom, your televison spot with Regis and Kelly, your meeting with the President and First Lady, the ovation you received at the school assembly? Did Mrs. Andrews really save you from been beaten to death in the hallway? Did you really risk your life to save her? Or did you just concoct all of these people and events in your little head to boost your little ego?
Your mind goes from seeing yourself as the world’s luckiest lover, to fearing you’re the world’s biggest chump.
And then the most horrid of possibilities hits you.
What if ...?
No, you reason with yourself, there must be a Mrs. Andrews. Yet who is she to you, really? Or maybe you should ask: who was she to you? After all, right now you don’t even know what year it is, or how old you are. At this point she could be an alluring flashback from your now distant high school past, a fetching memory from days gone by, yet one which has never ceased to captivate you in your dreams.
Or maybe she’s not so distant a memory at all. In fact, maybe you just met her.
Yes maybe, just maybe, you’re still in your first day of school. Maybe you right now are doing just what Julie told you to do on that day (which may be today): staying put after your last class, Mr. Lorenzo’s class, and waiting for her to pick you up. Yeah -- maybe you’re in Mr. Lorenzo’s classroom. And maybe, while waiting for Julie, you dozed off on his desk, with visions of your pretty new history teacher dancing in your head.
For by now you’re awake enough to realize that wherever you’ve been sleeping, it’s not in your own room.
1212221112112222222212211121121121221211.title: Rude Awakenings

1212221112112222222212211121121121221211.content:
As you slowly draw closer to consciousness, you begin seriously to doubt that you could be on Mr. Lorenzo’s desk. You certainly aren’t lying on anything like you’d find in a classroom. You rather seem to be facing inward on a couch, on the pink, velvet cushions of a couch.
To get your bearings, you twist your face around and look outward. Now you’re sure you’re not in a classroom. You’re not even inside. As your eyes adjust to the sunlight, you notice stretching out in front of you the end of a beach towel, an expanse of sand, Julie’s shoeless feet, and on the horizon between her legs, a row of familiar bungalows. Ah, you’re at Hadley Beach. But what on earth are you lying upon?
“Hey Rumplestilskin!”
“You mean Rip Van Winkle, stupid!”
“Oh ... yeah, well, you’re a crabby little man, so I’m still right. Anyway, Mom says come on, you gotta get ready.”
Ready? you ask yourself. Ready for what?
Julie doesn’t elaborate. Instead, her voice switches to a more respectful tone. That can only mean she’s addressing someone else.
1212221112112222222212211121121121221211.title: Seeing the Light

1212221112112222222212211121121121221211.content:
“Oh, and, um ... excuse me, Mrs. -- eee-oops! I gotta start calling you Teresa.”
“Mm-hmm.”
“Well anyway, Mom wanted me to wake you up, too, so you won’t be late.”
“Uh-huh. Thanks Julie. We’ll be there in a minute.”
Julie’s feet about face, and race back up to your bungalow.
That voice! That was ... her voice, Mrs. Andrew’s voice. Yet why should Julie be calling Mrs. Andrews by her first name?
But at least now you know what you’re lying upon. You’re not on a couch at all. And these pink cushions aren’t upholstered in velvet. They’re made of soft, velvety flesh. Her flesh.
She must be lying tummy down on the beach, and ...
You now look up, to see the sole of her foot towering over you.
Yep, you’re lying on the underside of her toes.
“Watch out honey,” she says. “Here I come.”
The toes of her other foot scrape down the sole of the foot you’re on, until they scoop you up, and gently deposit you on the towel.
You see her enormous, shapely legs draw themselves in, as her whole body, clad in a two piece bathing suit, rises to a sitting position, and stretches. She then dons her straw hat, looks down at you and smiles. She picks you up and sets you behind her beach bag. You can tell by the sound of flapping that she is shaking the sand off her towel, and soon, she stuffs the towel and her sunglasses in her bag, grabs the strap of the bag in one hand, and you in the other. She starts walking toward your bungalow.
“Where are we going?”
“To the bungalow, of course.”
“No, I mean after that.”
“My, we are sleepy, aren’t we? To the rehearsal.”
“The rehearsal? You mean, like a wedding rehearsal?”
“Mmm-hmmm.”
“Whose?”
“Guess.”
“Pierre and Stacie’s?”
“No, but -- they’ll be there. In fact they’re maid of honor and best man.”
“Elissa’s?”
“She’s a bridesmaid.”
You look helplessly perplexed. She stops walking and smiles down at you.
“You silly man. What do you think this is?”
She holds up the back of her hand, to display an engagement ring.
Immediately you look down at your own hand. Your face drops. There’s no ring.
1212221112112222222212211121121121221211.title: Ahhhhh!

1212221112112222222212211121121121221211.content:
She looks on your pained expression, more touched than amused. Bending down close to you, she whispers: “Men don’t always wear engagement rings.”
Oh. OH YES. Now you remember:
Men don’t always wear engagement rings, and the wedding ring alone, custom made to fit your tiny finger, was as much as the local jeweler could handle.
Impulsively you snuggle your fiancée’s thumb and barrage it with kisses. She pries you off her thumb, and sets you in her hand. She purses her gigantic lips and slowly leans toward you as you lay there, ecstatically helpless, awaiting one of her long, passionate, totally debilitating, thoroughly exhilarating kisses -- just like in your dream.
Only this time it isn’t a dream. It’s better than a dream.
It’s a dream come true.
1212221112112222222212211121121121221211.title: The Way it Ought to Be
